ygData.subject: Re: [neat] New Publication on Evolving the HyperNEAT Substrate
ygData.msgSnippet: ... Nice work, I really like the approach. I agree with the discussion at the end regarding quad/hyper-trees not necessarily being the last word, that was one

On 23 March 2010 21:39, Ken <kstanley@...> wrote:
>
> After years of speculation on how the placement and density of nodes might be evolved in
> the HyperNEAT substrate, Sebastian Risi, Joel Lehman, and I are pleased to announce
> our contribution to this conversation. Our paper, "Evolving the Placement and Density of
> Neurons in the HyperNEAT Substrate," which will be presented at GECCO this year

Nice work, I really like the approach. I agree with the discussion at
the end regarding quad/hyper-trees not necessarily being the last
word, that was one of my first thoughts. And that ties in to some
extent with the issue about number of nodes being generated being more
than was strictly required - perhaps variant approaches could be more
conservative in how many nodes they produce, although there are
pruning params already that influence this. The image of the evolved
ANN was interestingly asymetric as well I thought, it had a natural
look to it.

Overall though I think the obvious approach to evolving substrate is
to co-evolve it independently, so it was nice to (A) show an
alternative which probably will spark a range of news ideas, and (B)
demonstrate the independently co-evolved substrate might actually be
inferior to an ES-NEAT like approach.

It will be interesting to see this approach develop and be applied to
progressivley more difficult tasks.

Colin
